A grim hunt for answers

The New York Yankees observed a moment of silence for Boston before last night's game at Yankee Stadium. AP Photo/ Kathy Willens
Yankees fans even joined in the singing of Fenway staple "Sweet Caroline" in honor of their Boston brothers and sisters. AP Photo/ Kathy Willens
Mourners attended a candlelight vigil for Martin Richard at Garvey Park, near Richard's home in Dorchester. AP photo/the New York Times, Josh Haner
This image shows the remains of a pressure cooker that the FBI said was part of one of the bombs that exploded during the Boston Marathon. AP Photo/FBI
This image shows the remains of a black backpack that the FBI said contained one of the bombs that exploded during the Boston Marathon. AP Photo/FBI
Lizzie Lee, 56, of Lynwood, Wash. held a candle and a flower at Boston Common during a vigil for the victims of the Boston Marathon explosions. Julio Cortez/AP photo
A child waved a flag while attending a vigil for victims of the Boston Marathon bombings at Boston Commons. Spencer Platt/Getty Images
A man held a candle during a candlelight vigil in Dorchester, where eight-year-old Boston Marathon explosion victim Martin Richard lived. Bryan Snyder/Reuters
Jocelyn Lescarbeau (second left) comforted her sister Justine Lescarbeau, both of Boston, as they read a banner with well wishes during a vigil. Essdras M Suarez/ Globe Staff
A young girl cried with her mother during the vigil for eight-year-old Martin Richard, from Dorchester, who was killed by an explosion. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
People hugged and cried during a vigil for victims of the Boston Marathon bombings at the Boston Common. Spencer Platt/Getty Images
Martin Richard, 8, of Dorchester, was one of the victims of Monday's bombings. Courtesy of Richard family
Boston College senior Marissa Irwin, a marathoner, left a flower at a police barricade. Matthew Cavanaugh/EPA
